journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part O: Journal of Risk and Reliability

title-group.article-title: On profust reliability of coherent systems: signature-based expressions

contrib-group.aff: Department of Industrial Engineering, Atilim University, Ankara, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Serkan Eryilmaz, Department of Industrial Engineering, Atilim University, Incek, Ankara 06836, Turkey. Email: seryilmaz@atilim.edu.tr

abstract.p: In this article we study profust reliability of non-repairable coherent systems through the concept of system signature. We obtain explicit expressions for the profust reliability and mean time to fuzzy failure of coherent systems. We compute and present mean time to failure and mean time to fuzzy failure of all coherent systems with three and four components. Finally, we illustrate the results for a well known class of coherent systems called m-consecutive-k-out-of-n:F.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
In a traditional set-up of system reliability under binary state assumption, the value of system’s reliability is not discriminated with respect to the number of failed components. Consider a system that functions if at least k of its n components function, i.e. the system has a k-out-of-n:G structure. Assume that
n − k
components have failed and the system is working with k components, the system should have less reliability than the system has when
n − k − 1
components have failed and the other
k + 1
components are functioning. Such a situation can be modeled by using a fuzzy state approach. This approach has been considered in Guan and Wu1 to study the reliability of repairable consecutive k-out-of-n:F systems. A consecutive k-out-of-n:F system is a system that consists of n components, and fails if there are at least k consecutive failed components. The combination of probability assumption of system failure with the fuzzy state assumption of system success and failure creates a profust reliability theory, which was developed by Cai et al.2 Profust reliability theory has been successfully applied in various engineering systems (see for example Wu,3 Pandey and Tyagi,4 Mirakrabi and Ganji).5

In this article, we study the profust reliability of non-repairable coherent systems through the concept of system signature. The profust reliability theory combines both the probability and fuzzy assumptions on systems. Detailed explanations are presented in ‘Signature-based expressions’. We do not make any assumption on the structure of the system, and the lifetime distribution of its components.

The concept of signature is a structure-based characteristic of a system. It is defined by the vector

For a coherent system consisting of n independent and identically distributed component lifetimes, the behavior of the system’s lifetime is completely determined by the underlying component lifetime distribution and its signature. System signature has been found to be very useful in reliability studies. Some discussions on signature-based analysis of systems are in Kochar et al.,8 Navarro et al.,9 Samaniego et al.,10 Navarro and Rychlik,11 Navarro et al.,12 Triantafyllou and Koutras,13 Eryilmaz et al.,14 Mahmoudi and Asadi,15 and Eryilmaz.16 An extensive review of the signature of a coherent system and its applications is presented in Samaniego.6

The present article is organized as follows. In ‘Signature-based expressions’, we obtain signature-based expressions for the profust reliability and mean time to fuzzy failure of coherent systems. This section also includes illustrative examples. We then apply our results to m-consecutive-k-out-of-n:F systems.

Profust reliability was developed by Cai et al.,2 and is based on probability and fuzzy state assumptions. According to the probability assumption, the system failure is characterized by probability measure. Fuzzy state assumption implies that at any time the system can be in one of the two fuzzy states as either fuzzy success state or fuzzy failure state. Fuzzy state assumption means that system failure cannot be defined in a precise way.
The system profust reliability is then defined as
As is clear from equation (5), the profust reliability measure is a function of both membership function and the probability measure.

sec.title: Applications to m-consecutive-k-out-of-n:F systems
sec.p:
A linear consecutive k-out-of-n:F system is a system consisting of n linearly ordered components, and fails if there are at least k consecutive failed components. As a generalization of this system, a linear m-consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system consists of n linearly ordered components such that the system fails if there are at least m non-overlapping runs of k consecutive failed components (
n ≥ mk
). If “0” and “1” represent, respectively, the working and failed states for the components, then for
n = 15 , m = 3 , k = 2
and 110111100000100 the system is in a failed state since this sequence includes three non-overlapping failure runs of length
k = 2
. For
n = 15 , m = 3 , k = 3
the system is in a working state because there is only one failure run of length
k = 3
. These system models appear in many real life situations, including telecommunication networks, oil pipeline systems, and manufacturing processes. Consecutive k-out-of-n systems have attracted considerable attention in the field of reliability. An oil pipeline system with n pump stations can be modeled as a linear consecutive k-out-of-n:F system. For more detailed examples, see Guan and Wu.1

The m-consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system generalizes consecutive k-out-of-n:F and m-out-of-n:F systems for
m = 1
and
k = 1
, respectively. For this system

In Table 3, we compute the MTTF and MTTFF of various m-consecutive-k-out-of-n:F systems. It should be noted that these calculations can be done not only for exponential distribution, but also for any lifetime distribution. The difference between MTTF and MTTFF becomes larger with an increase in m or k, while it becomes smaller with an increase in n.

caption.p: Mean time to failure and mean time to fuzzy failure for m-consecutive-k-out-of-n:F systems.

sec.p:
For
m = 1 , n = 8 ,
and
k = 3
, the m-consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system reduces to a consecutive 3-out-of-8:F system. The profust reliability of repairable consecutive 3-out-of-8:F system was studied in Guan and Wu1 when both the working (with parameter λ) and repair (with parameter μ) time distributions of components are exponential. Our results are consistent with the results in Guan and Wu,1 when
μ = 0 .
Furthermore, we do not make any assumption on working time distribution of components.

This result is the same as the result that is obtained as a solution of the system of differential equations in Guan and Wu1 when

sec.title: Summary and conclusions
sec.p: In a conventional study of binary coherent systems, the number of failed components is not taken into account for system reliability when the system works. By using the fuzzy-state approach based on the profust method, which was proposed by Guan and Wu,1 we have considered the influence of the number of failed components on the reliability of a system.

We have obtained signature-based expressions for the profust reliability and the mean time to fuzzy failure of a coherent system consisting of independent and identically distributed component failure times. The novelty of the present article lies in the inclusion of system signature for studying profust reliability of a coherent system. We have illustrated the results for consecutive type systems, and obtained the same results as in Guan and Wu1 for a non-repairable consecutive k-out-of-n:F systems without using Kolmogorov differential equations. Possible future work might focus on reliability evaluation of a repairable system with fuzzy states through the concept of signature.

ack.p: The author wishes to thank two anonymous referees for their useful comments and suggestions that improved the article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
